p.s: The speech can be devideddivided into four paragraphs.
In the first paragraph Johnson talks baout his topic of the speech, the climate crisis by comparing it to ana film.
The main characters in it are the doomsday device (l. 3), a fictive bomb as a metaphorametaphor for the climate crisis and the agent James Bond, who is a metaphorametaphor for the global leaders.
To adress his idea of the climate crisis he uses a lot of including language everybody (l. 1) or speaking in third person we know (l. 8).
His metaphorasmetaphors are mentmeant to point out his view too.
It's also easier for the people that are listening to think of the problem, if you can connect it with pictures in your mind, like in a film or movie.
Although Johnson compares the climate change with a fictive movie, he titled it as a tragedy (l. 6) and underlines that it is a real problem and that we don't live in a movie.
The results of an danjoure like a bomb or a crisis are the same.
If one of them really happened, it will end in a catastrophic.
In the second part Johnson talks about his personal experiences of summits or political meetings about the climate crisis.
He takes the listeneres back in the years by making an allusion to Copenhagen and Paris (ll. 10f).
He reflectreflects the achievements they already made, for example that they acknowledged that climate is a problem or the agreement about the limit of 1.5 degrees in Paris (ll. 10-13).

Next to the achievements they already have made he critizisescriticizes that the promises that they are made are not going to happenedhappen if there will be no action by the governments of the global leaders (ll. 13f).
This is the task of the COP26.
In the third paragraph he points out that the action we have to take are absolutely possible.
He says, that we have the technology to end this catastrophic (l. 16).
He gives the audience hope by showing the option to move ot green energy (l. 21).
But to reach this goal, Johnson says that it is important to get away of coal and using funds to help other contriescountries financial with it.
It's the task of the global leaders to work together and in cooperation with banks of organisations to make progress.
No government will succeed if it works only by itself.
Looking to his country, Great Britain, he wants to end their depencedependence on coal and replace it by wind energy.
In the fourth and last paragraph Johnson talks about the effects of climate change and its crisis on the future.
He points out that the next generation are the ones that are going to suffer under the effects of the climate crisis.
It is the job of the COP26 to take action.
It's too late to fail because if they would fail (l. 39) it would be a turning point in the history of humanity.
COP26 will not, and cannot, be the end of the story of climate change(ll. 42f).
And to reach this Johnson saysays that they have everything they need.
The money, corporations and NGOs (l. 40), like Greenpeace.
In his Fazit Johnson talks directly to the listeners.
He says that all of them may not be like James Bond, but everyone of them have to begin to defuse the bomb, that means to take action against climate change (ll. 47-51).
The alliterations turn the tide (l. 50) underlines his message.
In the end he warns, that the fight will be hard, but gives hope by saying that we can do it (l. 51).
